title: List of United States presidential elections in which the winner lost the popular vote
deleted: There have been four [[United States presidential election]]s in which the successful presidential candidate did not receive a plurality of the popular vote, including the [[1824 United States presidential election|1824 election]], which was the first U.S. presidential election where the [[Direct election|popular vote]] was recorded.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.history.com/this-day-in-history/presidential-election-goes-to-the-house |title=1824 Presidential election goes to the House |publisher=[[History (U.S. TV channel)|History]] |access-date=December 10, 2016 |archive-date=December 3, 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161203175736/http://www.history.com/this-day-in-history/presidential-election-goes-to-the-house |url-status=live }}</ref> In these cases, the successful candidate secured less of the national popular vote than another candidate who received more votes, either a [[majority]], more than half the vote, or a [[Plurality (voting)|plurality]] of the vote.<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ubHhCgAAQBAJ&pg=PA172|title=Rethinking American Electoral Democracy|last=Streb|first=Matthew J.|date=October 30, 2015|publisher=Routledge|isbn=9781317519829|pages=172|language=en|oclc=928999469|access-date=February 2, 2017|archive-date=February 16, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170216025328/https://books.google.com/books?id=ubHhCgAAQBAJ&pg=PA172|url-status=live}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Savage|first=David|title=For the fourth time in American history, the president-elect lost the popular vote. Credit the electoral college|url=http://www.latimes.com/nation/la-na-pol-electoral-college-20161110-story.html|newspaper=[[Los Angeles Times]]|date=November 11, 2016|access-date=November 12, 2016|archive-date=November 12, 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161112004746/http://www.latimes.com/nation/la-na-pol-electoral-college-20161110-story.html|url-status=live}}</ref>

In the U.S. presidential election system, instead of the nationwide popular vote determining the outcome of the election, the [[president of the United States]] is determined by votes cast by electors of the [[United States Electoral College|Electoral College]]. Alternatively, if no candidate receives an entatives|House of Representatives]]. These procedures are governed by the [[Twelfth Amendment to the United States Constitution]].  It is important to note that the U.S. Constitution does not require states to hold a popular vote{{cn|date=February 2021}}, however, since [[1880 United States presidential election|1880]], electors in every state have been chosen based on a popular election held on [[Election Day (United States)|Election Day]].<ref name="CRS2017THN">{{cite web|last=Neale|first=Thomas H.|date=May 15, 2017|title=The Electoral College: How It Works in Contemporary Presidential Elections|url=https://fas.org/sgp/crs/misc/RL32611.pdf|access-date=July 29, 2018|work=CRS Report for Congress|publisher=Congressional Research Service|location=Washington, D.C.|page=13}}</ref>

When American voters cast ballots in a general presidential election, they are choosing electors. In 48 of the 50 states, state laws mandate the winner of the [[plurality voting|plurality]] of its statewide popular vote shall receive all of that state's electors;<ref name="auto2">{{Cite web|url=https://www.archives.gov/federal-register/electoral-college/about.html|title=What is the Electoral College?|website=National Archives|date=December 23, 2019|access-date=September 27, 2020}}</ref> in [[Maine]] and [[Nebraska]], two electors are assigned in this manner, while the remaining electors are allocated based on the plurality of votes in each of their [[congressional districts]].<ref>{{Cite web|date=March 6, 2020|title=Distribution of Electoral Votes |url=https://www.archives.gov/electoral-college/allocation|access-date=September 27, 2020|website=National Archives|language=en}}</ref> The federal district, [[Washington, D.C.]], allocates its 3 electoral votes to the winner of its single district election. States generally require electors to pledge to vote for that state's winning ticket; to avoid [[faithless electors]], most states have adopted various laws to enforce the electorsâ€™ pledge.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.fairvote.org/faithless_elector_state_laws|title=Faithless Elector State Laws|website=Fair Vote|date=July 7, 2020|access-date=July 7, 2020|quote=There are 33 states (plus the District of Columbia) that require electors to vote for a pledged candidate. Most of those states (16 plus DC) nonetheless do not provide for any penalty or any mechanism to prevent the deviant vote from counting as cast.}}</ref> The "national popular vote" is the sum of all the votes cast in the general election, nationwide. The presidential elections of [[1876 United States presidential election|1876]], [[1888 United States presidential election|1888]], [[2000 United States presidential election|2000]], and [[2016 United States presidential election|2016]] produced an Electoral College winner who did not receive the most votes in the general election.<ref>{{Cite book|last=Edwards III|first=George C.|title=Why the Electoral College is Bad for America|publisher=Yale University Press|edition=Second|year=2011|location=New Haven and London|isbn=978-0-300-16649-1}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.vox.com/policy-and-politics/2016/11/9/13572112/trump-popular-vote-loss |title=Trump will be the 4th president to win the Electoral College after getting fewer votes than his opponent |publisher=[[Vox (website)|Vox]] |date=November 9, 2016 |first=Alvin |last=Chang |access-date=November 11, 2016 |archive-date=November 10, 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161110235320/http://www.vox.com/policy-and-politics/2016/11/9/13572112/trump-popular-vote-loss |url-status=live }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.archives.gov/federal-register/electoral-college/key-dates.html|title=2016 Presidential Election|website=National Archives and Records Administration|access-date=November 26, 2016|archive-date=September 20, 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160920101721/https://www.archives.gov/federal-register/electoral-college/key-dates.html|url-status=live}}</ref> Additionally, in 14 other presidential elections (1844, 1848, 1856, 1860, 1880, 1884, 1892, 1912, 1916, 1948, 1960, 1968, 1992, and 1996), the winner received a plurality but not a majority of the total popular votes cast.

Of the four winners who lost the popular vote, three (Adams, Harrison, and Trump) ran for reelection four years later and lost the popular vote again and lost the election as well, one (Bush) ran and won the election as well as the popular vote, and one (Hayes) did not run for reelection.

In 1824, there were six states in which electors were legislatively appointed rather than popularly elected, meaning the 'national' popular vote in that election does not include all states and so its significance is uncertain. When no candidate received a majority of electoral votes in 1824, the election was decided by the House of Representatives. These circumstances distinguish the 1824 election from the latter four elections, which were all held after all states had instituted the popular selection of electors, and in which a single candidate won an outright majority of electoral votes, thus becoming president without a contingent election in the House of Representatives.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB109459688516011727 |title=Electoral College Mischief |work=The Wall Street Journal |date=September 8, 2004 |access-date=January 14, 2021 |archive-date=November 30, 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201130220409/https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB109459688516011727 |url-status=live }}</ref> The true national popular vote total was also uncertain in the [[1960 United States presidential election|1960 election]], and the plurality winner depends on how [[1960 United States presidential election in Alabama|votes for Alabama electors]] are allocated.<ref name="trende">{{cite news|title=Did JFK Lose the Popular Vote?|work=RealClearPolitics|date=October 22, 2012|url=http://www.realclearpolitics.com/articles/2012/10/19/did_jfk_lose_the_popular_vote_115833.html|access-date=October 23, 2012}}</ref>

The [[1824 United States presidential election|1824 presidential election]], held on October 26, 1824, was the first election in American history in which the popular vote mattered, as 18 states chose presidential electors by popular vote (six states still left the choice up to their state legislatures). When the final votes were tallied in those 18 states on December 1, [[Andrew Jackson]] polled 152,901 popular votes to [[John Quincy Adams]]'s 114,023; [[Henry Clay]] won 47,217, and [[William H. Crawford]] won 46,979. The electoral college returns, however, gave Jackson only 99 votes, 32 fewer than he needed for a majority of the total votes cast. Adams won 84 electoral votes followed by 41 for Crawford, and 37 for Clay when the Electoral College met on December 1, 1824.<ref name=JQAMC>{{cite web|title=John Quincy Adams: Campaigns and Elections|date=4 October 2016|publisher=Miller Center of Public Affairs, University of Virginia|url=http://millercenter.org/president/biography/jqadams-campaigns-and-elections#contributor|access-date=February 22, 2017|archive-date=February 23, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170223125212/http://millercenter.org/president/biography/jqadams-campaigns-and-elections#contributor|url-status=live}}</ref> All four candidates in the election identified with the [[Democratic-Republican Party]].

As no candidate secured the required number of votes (131 total) from the Electoral College, the election was decided by the [[United States House of Representatives|House of Representatives]] under the provisions of the [[Twelfth Amendment to the United States Constitution]]. As the 12th Amendment states the top three candidates in the electoral vote are candidates in the [[Contingent election#Presidential election of 1824|contingent election]], this meant Henry Clay, who finished fourth, was eliminated. As [[Speaker of the United States House of Representatives|Speaker of the House]], however, Clay was still the most important player in determining the outcome of the election.

The contingent election was held on February 9, 1825, with each state having one vote, as determined by the wishes of the majority of each state's congressional representatives. Adams narrowly emerged as the winner, with majorities of the Representatives from 13 out of 24 states voting in his favor. Most of Clay's supporters, joined by several old [[Federalist Party|Federalists]], switched their votes to Adams in enough states to give him the election. Soon after his inauguration as President, Adams appointed Henry Clay as his [[United States Secretary of State|secretary of state]].<ref name=JQAMC/> This result became a source of great bitterness for Jackson and his supporters, who proclaimed the election of Adams a "[[Corrupt bargain#Election of 1824|corrupt bargain]]," and were inspired to create the [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic Party]].<ref>[http://history1800s.about.com/od/leaders/a/electionof1824.htm "The Election of 1824 Was Decided in the House of Representatives: The Controversial Election was Denounced as 'The Corrupt Bargain'"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090307212214/http://history1800s.about.com/od/leaders/a/electionof1824.htm |date=2009-03-07 }}, Robert McNamara, About.com</ref><ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Stenberg | first1 = R. R. | title = Jackson, Buchanan, and the "Corrupt Bargain" Calumny | journal = The Pennsylvania Magazine of History and Biography | volume = 58 | issue = 1 | pages = 61â€“85 | year = 1934| jstor = 20086857 }}</ref>
